section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Alphabet Cards (Qq, Rr), Quack! Quack! Quiet!, Rain, drawing and writing supplies

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read Oscar and the Cricket. We saw the letter q in the word quickly and the letter r in the word rolling.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Teach Qq Alphabet Cards Show the Alphabet Cards for letter Qq. Say the letter aloud and have children repeat. This is uppercase Q. The letter Q makes the /kw/ sound you hear in the word quilt. This is lowercase q. The letter q makes the /kw/ sound you hear in the word queen.

Teach Rr Alphabet Cards Show the Alphabet Cards for letter Rr. Say the letter aloud and have children repeat. This is uppercase R. The letter R makes the /r/ sound you hear in the word rabbit. This is lowercase r. The letter r makes the /r/ sound you hear in the word ring.
Read Read aloud Quack! Quack! Quiet! and use the following prompt.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Quack when you hear a word that begins with the /q/ sound.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Read Read aloud Rain and use the following prompt.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Wiggle your fingers like rain falling down when you hear a word that begins with the /r/ sound.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Model Model writing uppercase and lowercase letters Qq and Rr. Provide drawing and writing supplies. Guide children in practicing forming their letters.

As you read Quack! Quack! Quiet!, stop at each word that begins with the letter Qq. Have children say /kw/ and the word that begins with Qq. Repeat with Rain and the letter Rr. Some children will benefit from tracing letters in trays of salt or sand.

For a challenge, after reading each story, ask children to try to recall all the words that begin with the target sound and letter. Then invite children to name any other words they know that begin with that letter and sound.
In Spanish, the letters qu have a /k/ sound and never make the /kw/ sound. Have children practice saying words that being with qu and have them emphasize the /kw/ sound.

Be sure to seat children with visual and/or auditory needs close to you. This will allow them to better hear the target sounds and see the positioning of your mouth as you enunciate the sound. If necessary, face children directly, make eye contact, and repeat the target sound.

section-block.ac_back_copyright_line: 978-1-338-65174-4. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Toy cars, masking tape

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we reread Oscar and the Cricket, a narrative about a curious cat named Oscar who learns about how things move by asking Cricket “why” questions.
Today, we will learn by asking “why” questions. We will try pushing them in different ways—with more force and less force—and on different surfaces—smooth and bumpy.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Model In Oscar and the Cricket, Oscar made the ball roll. I wonder why the ball moves when Oscar pushes it! Demonstrate pushing a car on the floor with little force and then with greater force.
Introduce the Surfaces Use masking tape to mark a “starting line” that runs across a section of floor and carpet. Let children choose a car.
section-block.ac_teacher-card-teacher_talk_bulleted: Tell children to decide how much force they will use. Give each child a turn to push their car on the floor to see how far it rolls. Mark the end point with tape.

Before using the carpet, remind children to try to use the same amount of force as they did on the floor. Then ask if they think their car will go farther on the carpet than on the floor. After each turn, ask: On which surface did your car go farther? I wonder why the car went farther?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Talk About It Ask questions about the activity.

ac_teacher-card-teacher_talk_bulleted.ac_teacher-speaking: Whose car went farther on the floor? Why do you think that is?
Do you think your car would go farther on the carpet if you used more force to push it? Why or why not?
What two things can change how far the car rolls?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Focus on one variable at a time—amount of force or type of surface. Have children roll their car along the floor only. Allow them to experiment with using greater or lesser force. Ask questions to guide children’s understanding.
Challenge children to try using different-sized cars on the floor and carpet. What observations can they make between the size and weight of a car and how far it rolls?

Set aside a specific time to preteach new lesson vocabulary to multilingual learners. If possible, teach lesson concepts—force, push, pull—in children’s native language first. Video clips, interactive tools, text-to-speech, and voice output have also shown to be beneficial tools in teaching science concepts to multilingual learners. Preview digital tools before sharing with children.

Children with motor challenges will have a more successful experience pushing larger toys, so be sure to include some much larger cars and trucks. If the child is able to grip a broom handle, they can slide a broom along the floor to push the car or truck.

section-block.ac_back_copyright_line: 978-1-338-65174-4. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials straws, shiny painting paper, cups of watercolor or tempera paints (labeled with color names), pipettes or eye droppers

Connect to Large Group Today we will learn more about how the forces of pushing and pulling cause things to move. Who remembers what caused the leaves to move in Oscar and the Cricket? Yes, the wind pushed the leaves! Hold your hand near your mouth (demonstrate a few inches) and blow on it.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In today’s activity, you will use the force of your breath to move paint across paper.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Model Place one or two drops of paint on your paper. Blow gently through a straw as you move it around to push the paint. Repeat, blowing a little harder. Explain that the painting does not have to look like something real. Children should just have fun being creative.

Assist Allow each child to choose a paint color. Squeeze a drop from the eye dropper or pipette onto their paper. Give each child a straw. Allow children to choose additional paint colors as they work.
Ask Guide children as they work on their paintings:

ac_teacher-card-teacher_talk_bulleted.ac_teacher-speaking: Try blowing gently through the straw first. Now blow harder.
What do you notice about how the paint moves when you blow gently and when you blow hard?
How can you make the paint move in a different direction?.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Talk About It Encourage children’s curiosity.

ac_teacher-card-teacher_talk_bulleted.ac_teacher-speaking: What force did you use to move the paint—push or pull?
What happened when two paint colors mixed together?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Assist children as needed by blowing through your own straw along with them. Guide them to push the paint around the paper by moving their straw. If they need help grasping the concept, move your finger around the paper and have children follow with their straw.
Challenge children to experiment with breathe control to push the paint in ways that form specific images. For example, a circle with short lines radiating from it could form the image of the sun.

Encourage multilingual learners to practice naming the different paint colors in English as they make their color choices. If they use their native language, acknowledge it and then say the color name in English while pointing to the label on the paint cup.

If children find holding and blowing through a straw too difficult, you can cut straws to provide shorter-lengths, or allow children to simply blow across the paper without using a straw. If you have access to a small, hand-held fan, children can also use the force of the fan to push the paint across their papers. Encourage them to adjust fan speeds and to notice the different effects on where the paint travels on the paper.

section-block.ac_back_copyright_line: 978-1-338-65174-4. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials paper (oversized), art supplies, The Great Big Enormous Yuca

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read the story The Great Big Enormous Yuca. We saw how everyone worked hard to pull the yuca from the ground because it was a great big enormous yuca.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Explain the Activity Let’s look at the great, big, enormous yuca on the chart. Can you think of other plants or animals that would be hard to move because they are great and big and enormous? Help children generate ideas. Their suggestions might include trees, dinosaurs, elephants, whales, eagles, and sharks.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today you are going to draw something that is great and big and enormous. Can you think of something you would like to draw?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Set out the supplies children will need. Show them how to hold the paper lengthwise so they have the largest space for drawing.

Do the Activity As children draw, talk about other words they might use to describe their plants or animals such as huge, tremendous, and gigantic. When children finish, help them label their drawings as A great, big, enormous .
Extend Help children write children’s names on their drawings and have them read them. Then ask children to write their names on their drawings.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: What can you tell us about the drawing you made? What does the label say?
Can you think of any other words to describe your drawing?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: By now children should be able to recognize their own names in writing. If they cannot, write their names in large letters. Show children three different names of children and ask the child to identify his own name. Then ask him to identify the first letter and choose it from a group of three Alphabet Cards.
Challenge children to describe the parts of the plant or animal they drew. Add the words they name to label the parts of the illustration. Then have children name the letters in the words you wrote.

To help expand children’s ability to describe their drawings, ask questions, such as Is this a plant or an animal? Is your animal little or huge? Is your animal small or tremendous? Does your animal walk on land or swim in the water? Does your animal have fins or legs?

Children who have difficulty drawing, especially on such a large scale, may find it helpful for you to draw the outline of the object they decided to draw. Then children can add the colors and the details to their drawings. If children still have difficult writing their names, watch them as they write and have them practice the letter(s) that are most challenging for them.

section-block.ac_back_copyright_line: 978-1-338-65174-4. TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.
